author: bmanikm
body:
This issue got reported in #1184.
As per #1184, PowerShellGet in  PowerShell Core on Windows should install the modules to the following locations.

``` powershell
CurrentUser scope: ~\Documents\PowerShell\Modules - User documents module location for PowerShell Core

AllUsers scope: %ProgramFiles%\PowerShell<version>\Modules - Module path for the specific instance of PowerShell Core that is running.

Similar locations for scripts:
CurrentUser scope: ~\Documents\PowerShell\Scripts
AllUsers scope: %ProgramFiles%\PowerShell<version>\Scripts

```
## Steps to reproduce

``` powershell
PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0.9> ls C:\Users\masae\Documents\PowerShell\Modules

PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0.9> ls C:\Users\masae\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\

PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0.9> (get-command Install-Module).Module.Path
C:\program files\powershell\6.0.0.9\Modules\PowerShellGet\PSModule.psm1

PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0.9> Install-Module zlocation -Scope CurrentUser

Untrusted repository
You are installing the modules from an untrusted repository. If you trust this repository, change its
InstallationPolicy value by running the Set-PSRepository cmdlet. Are you sure you want to install the modules from
'PSGallery'?
[Y] Yes  [A] Yes to All  [N] No  [L] No to All  [S] Suspend  [?] Help (default is "N"): A

PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0.9> ls C:\Users\masae\Documents\PowerShell\Modules

PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0.9> ls C:\Users\masae\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\


    Directory: C:\Users\masae\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Modules


Mode                LastWriteTime         Length Name
----                -------------         ------ ----
d-----       2016-08-21   4:27 PM                ZLocation


PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0.9>

```
## Expected behavior

As per #1184, PowerShellGet on Windows PowerShell Core should install the modules to the following locations.

``` powershell
CurrentUser scope: ~\Documents\PowerShell\Modules - User documents module location for PowerShell Core

AllUsers scope: %ProgramFiles%\PowerShell<version>\Modules - Module path for the specific instance of PowerShell Core that is running.

Similar locations for scripts:
CurrentUser scope: ~\Documents\PowerShell\Scripts
AllUsers scope: %ProgramFiles%\PowerShell<version>\Scripts

```
## Actual behavior

Captured in the repro steps.

comments.author: kilasuit
comments.body:
This brings an issue when running PowerShell 6 in side by side mode on windows due to the fact that this would require a change to PSModulePath for the modules to be found by Get-Module -ListAvailable

Take this example 

I install modules from the PowerShell Gallery when running PowerShell v 5.1 (Windows 10 AU +) which installs the module to C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules which is a path in my PSModulePath Environment Variable

Now when I load Powershell 6x it will be able to find modules in that path which _I do not want_
So to get round this I have to enforce that PSModulePath only has the C:\Program Files\PowerShell\Modules location defined as not to load any modules that require the full .NET framework.

So I would be suggestive of a breaking change for PowerShell Core and implement a completely new PSCoreModulePath env variable which would allow co-existence to occur with no issues to the underlying WindowsPowerShell install on a machine.

comments.author: masaeedu
comments.body: @kilasuit When you load PS6 it will not be able to find modules in `C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules`, because the PSModulePath is not changing. The location to which PowershellGet installs modules in PS6 is changing.

comments.author: kilasuit
comments.body: @masaeedu seems between 6.0.0.8 & 6.0.0.9 the PSModulePath has been changed to not load the actual entries that are listed in the Environmental variable which I seem to have missed where this change came in (hence before saying that I needed to edit the PSModulePath) For example see how my PSModulePath across 5.1.14905.1000 (left), 6.0.0.8 (middle) & 6.0.0.9 (right) are different as below However it brings the question as I couldn't work it out but what change was it that took place between 6.0.0.8 & 6.0.0.9 that modifies how PSModulePath env variable is populated.

title: Update PowerShellGet to install the modules and scripts to proper locations in PowerShell Core on Windows
